search.slidetext: 1.1 vertebral column resources hanging skeleton examples of isolated vertebrae from each of the vertebral regions, including an atlas/axis pair samples of articulated vertebrae with ligaments next what you’ll need: exercise selection

1.1 objectives next previous describe the components of the vertebral column. identify the features that are common to all vertebrae. identify the distinguishing features of the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar vertebrae. identify the features of the sacrum. describe the articulations of the vertebral column, including the intervertebral discs and the zygopophyseal joints. describe how the orientation of the zygopophyseal joints is different between the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar vertebrae, and how this influences mobility in each region. identify the ligaments of the vertebral column and understand their clinical significance in relation to herniated discs. 2

column using the hanging skeleton. use the numbers that follow to guide you. next identify the bones which comprise the vertebral previous the vertebral column is composed of 33 vertebrae divided into five regions. from superior to inferior, there are: seven cervical vertebrae (c1-c7), twelve thoracic vertebrae (t1-t12), five lumbar vertebrae (l1-l5), five sacral vertebrae (s1-s5), and usually four coccygeal vertebrae (co1-co4). the basic structure of all vertebrae is similar; however, vertebrae from these different regions have distinguishing characteristics. adjacent bony vertebrae are joined by articulations, thus forming the vertebral column. the integrity of the vertebral column is reinforced by ligaments. 1.1 overview of the vertebral column tas k 7 cervical vertebrae (ci-cvii) 12 thoracic vertebrae (ti-txii) 5 lumbar vertebrae (li-lv) sacrum (5 fused sacral vertebrae i-v) coccyx (3-4 fused coccygeal vertebrae i-iv) 3

from amongst those with which you’ve been provided. body vertebral arch (composed of the pedicles and laminae) vertebral foramen spinous process transverse processes superior and inferior articular processes, each with an articular facet next 1.1 common features of vertebrae previous you will start by identifying the structural features common to most vertebrae. the lumbar vertebrae are the largest. choose the largest vertebra identify the following features: tas k tas k 4

next previous the size of the vertebral body. lumbar vertebrae bear more body weight than those of the thoracic and cervical regions. the vertebral body is the weight-bearing element of a vertebra. therefore, you will find that when comparing vertebra from various regions of the vertebral column, the bodies of the lumbar vertebrae are the largest. of the spinous process of the lumbar vertebra in your hand; it is blunt, square and extends straight backwards from the vertebral (neural) arch. observe on the vertebra in your hand, note the shape these two characteristics help identify a vertebra as being from the lumbar region. tas k tas k 1.1 lumbar vertebrae are built for weight bearing 5

from amongst the vertebrae with which you have been provided. next 1.1 thoracic vertebrae articulate with ribs previous thoracic vertebrae are distinguished from those of the lumbar region by their smaller vertebral bodies and their characteristically long, slender and inferiorly-oriented spinous processes. in addition, since thoracic vertebrae articulate with the twelve pairs of ribs, there are costal facets on the bodies and transverse processes of thoracic vertebrae. with these identifying characteristics in mind, find a thoracic vertebra tas k vertebral body vertebral foramen note the articular facets on the superior and inferior articular processes. note the costal facets on the bodies and transverse processes of thoracic vertebrae. anterior superior anterior inferior posterior pedicle lamina facet for articulation with tubercle of rib superior demifacet superior articular process demifacet for articulation with head of rib inferior articular process facet for articulation with tubercle of rib superior view superolateral view transverse process spinous process posterior 6

and articulate it with the one in your hand. next previous and how the superior and inferior articular facets of adjacent vertebrae articulate with one another. pick up another thoracic vertebra note how they fit together of adjacent vertebrae aligns the vertebral foramina, thus creating the vertebral canal, which houses the spinal cord and its soft coverings. observe how articulation between the pedicles of the adjacent vertebrae that is created when two vertebrae are articulated with one another. this space is called the intervertebral foramen . bilaterally -paired spinal nerves emerge from between adjacent vertebrae through the intervertebral foramina. note the foramen tas k tas k tas k tas k 1.1 the vertebral canal and intervertebral foramina 7

from amongst the disarticulated vertebrae you’ve been given. to a typical thoracic vertebra, a cervical vertebra has a relatively larger vertebral foramen, a smaller, bifid spinous process and its transverse processes are characterized by the presence of the transverse foramina (s. transverse foramen). next previous a typical cervical vertebra has a smaller body as compared to that of a thoracic vertebra, and has no costal facets. with this in mind, find a cervical vertebra note that in comparison tas k tas k 1.1 cervical vertebrae the vertebral arteries thread through these openings on their way from the subclavian arteries to the brainstem. 8

the first and second cervical vertebrae are structurally and functionally different from other vertebrae. a. c1 is the atlas ; it supports the skull. the atlas does not have a vertebral body, and thus consists largely of a ring of bone. b. c2 is the axis; it is characterized by the presence of the dens . the dens is formed during development when the body of c1 becomes fused to that of c2. next previous 1.1 the atlas and axis 9

and stack the atlas on top of the axis, fitting the dens into the anterior arch of the atlas. in life, the dens is held in place by the transverse ligament, and the atlas can rotate around the dens, as when you shake your head “no”. next previous amongst the vertebrae with which you have been provided are an atlas and axis, tied together with a string. pick up c1 and c2 and notice how the superior articular facets of the atlas articulate with the occipital condyles of the skull. it is at these bilaterally paired articulations that you nod your head “yes”. look at the hanging skeleton tas k tas k 1.1 articulating the atlas and axis palpate it at the base of your neck tas k as you tip your head forward to feel the vertebra prominens. 10 the last cervical vertebra of note is c7, the vertebra prominens. it has a particularly prominent spinous process;

that correspond to those of a vertebrae. on the posterior surface: next previous the sacrum begins embryologically as five separate sacral vertebrae that fuse by physical maturity to form a single bone. using the hanging skeleton, identify the features of the sacrum and spinous tubercles , formed from the spinous processes of the sacral vertebrae, the posterior sacral foramina, derived from note the median sacral crest tas k tas k 1.1 the posterior surface of the sacrum identify the sacral canal, tas k which is the continuation of the vertebral canal, and opens inferiorly as the sacral hiatus. coccygeal nerves and the filum terminale externa arise from the sacral hiatus (see exercise 1.4). 11 the intervertebral foramen, and the lateral sacral crest , derived from the transverse processes. dorsal rami of sacral spinal nerves emerge from the posterior sacral foramina to supply overlying muscle and skin; e.g. the dorsal rami of s1 emerges from the most superior of the posterior sacral foramina, etc.

which is formed from 3-5 rudimentary coccygeal vertebrae. the usual number is four, denoted co1 - co4. next previous on the anterior (pelvic) surface of the sacrum (a feature of the s1 vertebral body), and the remnants of the remaining sacral vertebral bodies. note the sacral promontory the ventral rami of sacral spinal nerves emerge from the anterior sacral foramina, the ventral rami of s1 emerging from the most superior pair, etc. lastly, notice the anterior sacral foramina tas k tas k 1.1 the anterior surface of the sacrum identify the coccyx, tas k 12

next previous 1.1 progress check 1 13 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: count to identify specific vertebra when presented with a bony spine features common among vertebrae, e.g. body, arch, pedicle, lamina, vertebral foramen, spinous process, transverse process, superior and inferior articular processes and their facets, etc. features of a vertebra that localize it to a specific region of the vertebral column (body size, peculiarities of the processes, presence of facets, etc.); what is the vertebra prominens? the atlas and axis; describe their distinguishing features; what is the dens? what is the transverse ligament and what does it do? compare and contrast the vertebral foramen and vertebral canal from the intervertebral foramen the characteristic features of the sacrum, e.g. median sacral crest, spinous tubercles, anterior and posterior sacral foramina, lateral sacral crest, sacral canal, sacral hiatus, sacral promontory, etc.; what, specifically, arise from the anterior and posterior sacral foramina? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the exercise.

next previous with age, wear and tear, info 1.1 invertebral discs an intervertebral disc can herniate , such that the nucleus pulposus pushes through the annulus fibrosis into the intervertebral foramen, thus compressing a spinal nerve or its root. 14 each vertebral body is joined to the next by an intervertebral disc, which consists of an outer, tough, fibrocartilaginous annulus fibrosus , and a gelatinous core called the nucleus pulposus . the intervertebral disc offers tough, flexible support; the highly hydrated nucleus pulposis withstands compression and is very deformable, thereby permitting flexion , extension and rotation of the vertebral column.

next previous you have been provided with two specimens of articulated vertebrae with their associated ligaments. one specimen has been sectioned in the midsagittal plane. the other has been sectioned through the pedicles, thereby separating the vertebral bodies from the neural arch. on both specimens, 1.1 the annulus fibrosus and nucleus pulposus identify tas k and on the sagittally-sectionedspecimen, identify tas k the intervertebral disc, the annulus fibrosus andthe nucleus pulposus. 15

next previous the superior and inferior articular processes of adjacent vertebrae are joined by synovial joints called zygopophyseal joints. 1.1 zygopophyseal joints on the specimens provided, and note their fibrous joint capsules. identify the location of the zygopophyseal joints tas k 16

next previous the orientation of the zygopophyseal joints varies in different regions of the spinal column and thereby influences the range of movement between adjacent vertebrae around the three possible axes. 1.1 regional variation of zygopophyseal joints cervical thoracic lumbar “sloped from anterior to posterior” zygapophysial joint zygapophysial joint zygapophysial joint “vertical” “wrapped” lateral view lateral view lateral view superior view 17

some of the ligaments reinforcing the vertebral column are segmental, extending from one vertebra to the next, while others are continuous, running the length of the vertebral column. next previous 1.1 segmental ligaments of the vertebral column find the following segmental ligaments tas k the ligamenta flava have a particularly high content of elastic fibres, and thus provide more “give” than most ligaments. on the specimens provided: 1) the interspinous ligaments, which join the spinous processes of adjacent vertebrae 2) the ligamenta flava (s. ligamentum flavum), which join the laminae of adjacent vertebrae ligamenta flava ligamenta flava vertebral canal interspinous ligament supraspinous ligament supraspinous ligament ligamentum flavum ligamentum flavum posterior inferior anterior posterior superior 18

next previous on the specimens provided, 1.1 longitudinal ligaments of the vertebral column find the following longitudinal ligaments tas k 1) the supraspinous ligament, which connects the spinous processes of the vertebrae. 2) the posterior longitudinal ligament, a narrow band that connects the posterior aspect of the vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs. 3) the anterior longitudinal ligament, a broad band that connects the anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs. which run continuously along the length of the vertebral column: 19

next previous 1.1 clinical significance: herniated discs longitudinal ligaments reinforce the anterior and posterior aspects of the intervertebral discs, a herniated disc most commonly protrudes laterally into the intervertebral foramen, compressing a spinal nerve or its roots. because the anterior and posterior info 20

next previous 1.1 progress check 2 21 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: describe and demonstrate flexion, extension, lateral flexion, and left / right rotation of the vertebral column intervertebral disc, annulus fibrosus, nucleus pulposus, zygopophyseal joints; what is their structural classification? how does their orientation differ between vertebral regions? how does this affect movement in each region? vertebral ligaments: interspinous, ligamenta flava, supraspinous, posterior and anterior longitudinal ligaments; which are segmental and which are longitudinal? why do intervertebral discs tend to herniate laterally? what neural structures are usually impinged upon by a herniated disc? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the exercise.
next previous 1.1 quiz skip 22 press or swipe next to start the quiz or skip to end exercise 1.1.

unit 1 overview previous next in unit 1, students are introduced to the body wall, its contents and innervation. unit 1 is comprised of 3 six-hour laboratory periods that are either split up over 2 half days, or occur over the course of one full day. during each of the three labs students will complete 4 separate exercises. within a given lab room, students are divided into four lab groups of 8 - 9 students. these are designated lab groups a-d. the students within each of these groups will dissect, learn from, and share the care of two cadavers, one male and one female, for the duration of the academic year. each lab group (a-d) is divided into lab pairs 1-4 and each pair starts the lab on the exercise that corresponds to their pair number. pairs will have approximately 90 minutes to complete the tasks associated with a given exercise before the ta announces that it is time to rotate to the next exercise. students are not permitted to move from one station to the next until instructed to do so by the ta. if the station involves dissection, the first pair will start the dissection. after 90 minutes, the next pair will continue dissecting where the last pair left off. in most cases, the dissection will not be completed until the fourth group contributes, which means earlier pairs must circle back to see the completed work. if you are done all of the tasks at a station and completed the end-of-exercise quiz in quizlandia before it is time to rotate, click on the “field trip” button. this provides you with a list of specimens to look at in grant’s museum of anatomy, ms1150, to enhance your understanding of the material presented in the lab. all students must prepare for each lab session by completing the prelab slm(s). each lab session begins with an app-based lab rat on the prelab slm(s). in the case of a full-day lab, students will complete two rats, one at the start of the morning session, and another at the start of the afternoon session. it is imperative that students also preview the lab exercises that they will complete during the session in order to derive the most benefit out of the practical laboratory experience.

lab 1 instructions previous next prior to lab 1, you will complete exercise 1a, a short self-learning module (slm) that teaches you some basic anatomical nomenclature, and exercise 1b, a short slm that introduces you to the nervous system. these are to be completed before the lab. lab will begin with an app-based quiz on these two slms. during lab you will complete exercises 1.1 - 1.4, in which you will study the vertebral column, spinal cord, spinal nerves and be introduced to a somatic nerve plexus. the material for these exercises will be placed at four different stations around your lab room. you will work and rotate with your pairs: if you are done all of the tasks at a station and completed the end of exercise quiz in quizlandia before it is time to rotate, click on the “field trip” button. here you will find a list of specimens to look at in grant’s museum of anatomy, ms1150, to help build your understanding of the material presented within the lab. exercise week 1 1:00-2:30 week 1 2:30-4:00 week 3 9:00-10:30 week 3 10:30-12:00 1.1 pairs 1 pairs 4 pairs 3 pairs 2 1.2 pairs 2 pairs 1 pairs 4 pairs 3 1.3 pairs 3 pairs 2 pairs 1 pairs 4 1.4 pairs 4 pairs 3 pairs 2 pairs 1

1.2 spinal cord and meninges resources prosected spinal cord in situ models of articulated vertebral column with sacrum or pelvis next what you’ll need: exercise selection

next previous describe where spinal nerves exit the vertebral column. describe the convention by which spinal nerves are numbered, and why spinal nerves in the cervical region are numbered differently than the rest of the spinal cord. describe the formation of a spinal nerve. describe the length of the spinal cord relative to the vertebral column, and its clinically significance with regard to the site of a lumbar puncture. describe the meninges and their role in covering and anchoring the spinal cord. 2 1.2 objectives

seven cervical (c1 -c7) vertebrae 12 thoracic (t1 -t12) vertebrae five lumbar (l1 -l5) vertebrae sacrum (formed by the fusion of five sacral vertebrae, s1 -s5) coccyx (formed by the fusion of 4 vertebrae, co1 - co4) next note the: previous 1.2 vertebral regions tas k the spinal cord, its soft coverings, fat, and blood vessels occupy the vertebral canal. on the articulated vertebral column model provided, 7 cervical vertebrae (ci-cvii) 12 thoracic vertebrae (ti-txii) 5 lumbar vertebrae (li-lv) sacrum (5 fused sacral vertebrae i-v) coccyx (3-4 fused coccygeal vertebrae i-iv) 3

between the pedicles of adjacent vertebrae. next 1.2 intervertebral foramina and spinal nerves previous note the intervertebral foramina tas k 4 bilaterally paired spinal nerves are located in the intervertebral foramina.

spinal nerves are numbered according to adjacent vertebrae. from the thoracic region caudally, spinal nerves emerge below their corresponding vertebra. for example, the t1 spinal nerves lie in the intervertebral foramina below the t1 vertebra and the l1 spinal nerves lie in the intervertebral foramina below the l1 vertebra. using the vertebral column provided, next 1.2 naming of spinal nerves previous 5 present each other with a vertebra at or below the tas k thoracic level, including the sacrum and coccyx. have your colleagues name the spinal nerve that emerges above and below it.

next 1.2 cervical spinal nerves are named differently previous using a probe, count down until you locate the intervertebral foramen from which the c8 spinal nerve emerges. you will have identified the intervertebral foramen between the c7 and t1 vertebrae. 6 place a probe above the c1 vertebra. this is where the c1 spinal nerve emerges from the vertebral canal. count the cervical vertebrae, c1 - c7. tas k there are eight pairs of cervical spinal nerves, while there are only seven cervical vertebrae. present each other with a cervical vertebra. tas k have your colleagues name the spinal nerve that emerges above and below it. thus, other than the c8 spinal nerve, cervical spinal nerves emerge above their corresponding vertebra.

identify the spinous processes and laminae of the vertebrae. the laminae extend from the transverse processes to the spinous processes. next look at the posterior aspect of the bony vertebral column provided and previous 1.2 a laminectomy exposes the spinal cord in situ tas k in order to study the spinal cord in situ, a laminectomy is performed. the laminae are cut bilaterally and the spinous processes of each vertebra are removed. this opens the vertebral canal and exposes the spinal cord from the posterior aspect. 7

and identify the spinal cord within the spinal canal. notice that the spinal cord is shorter than the vertebral column. next unwrap the specimen of the spinal cord in situ previous 1.2the spinal cord ends adjacent to the l2 vertebral body tas k identify the tip of the spinal cord, the conus medullaris, which is typically adjacent to the l2 vertebral body. 8

next previous 1.2 the formation of a spinal nerve bearing in mind that you are looking at the spinal cord from its dorsal aspect, identify dorsal and tas k ventral rootlets. dorsal and ventral rootlets emerge from their respective surfaces of the spinal cord, and coalesce to form dorsal and ventral roots. these join to form a spinal nerve as they exit the intervertebral foramen. 9

next previous 1.2 spinal segments follow pairs of rootlets caudally toward tas k the rootlets arise from the segment of the spinal cord associated with its respective nerve. their point of exit from the spinal canal. observe that because the spinal cord is shorter tas k than the vertebral column, 10 the dorsal and ventral rootlets increase in length from rostral to caudal as they descend to form a spinal nerve in their respective intervertebral foramen, and the spinal segments are increasingly removed from their corresponding vertebra.

next previous 1.2 the spinal meninges the spinal cord is enclosed in three layers of membranous coverings, the meninges. from superficial to deep, the meninges are the dura , arachnoid , and the pia mater. the dura and arachnoid form the dural sac. 11

next previous 1.2 the dural sac the dural sac extends from the foramen magnum of the occipital bone to end at the level of the s2 vertebral body. identify the dura mater in your specimen. tas k 12 it will appear as a tough layer that has been slit down the midline. in order to see the spinal cord, you will have reflected the two parts of the dura laterally, opening them like a book, thereby revealing the spinal cord.

the denticulate ligaments are extensions of the pia mater that anchor the spinal cord bilaterally to the inner surface of the dural sac, thereby stabilizing the spinal cord. next previous 1.2 the subarachnoid space contains csf the spinal cord, covered in pia mater, lies within the dural sac in the sub arachnoid space. in life, the subarachnoid space is filled with cerebrospinal fluid (csf), the fluid that bathes the brain and spinal cord. the plane between the dura and arachnoid, unlike the subarachnoid space, is a potential space. this means that in life, the arachnoid is held against the dura by the hydrostatic pressure of the csf in the subarachnoid space. 13 identify the denticulate ligaments in your specimen. tas k they will appear as saw-tooth-shaped extensions from the lateral aspect of the cord. because the subarachnoid space was opened in the preparation of your specimen, the csf drained out and the arachnoid has fallen away from the dura and onto the spinal cord.

the lumbar cistern is an expansion of the subarachnoid space, and thus, in life, contains csf. identify the other contents of the lumbar cistern, the cauda equina and filum terminale interna. the cauda equina consists of lumbar and sacral spinal rootlets descending to their points of exit from the subarachnoid space and vertebral canal. next previous 1.2 the lumbar cistern identify the location of the lumbar cistern : tas k it is within the dural sac, extending from the conus medullaris, at the level of the l2 vertebra, to the end of the dural sac, at the level of the s2 vertebral body. 14 site of a lumbar puncture, a procedure in which csf is withdrawn via a needle the lumbar cistern is the info inserted between the l3 and l4 vertebrae.

the epi dural (extradural) space lies between the dura and the bony vertebral canal. in life, the epidural space is filled with adipose tissue and a rich venous plexus. next previous 1.2 the epidural space info identify the epidural space tas k in your specimen, in life, it is filled with fat and the internal vertebral venous plexus. this is the site of injection of epidural anesthetic, a which is commonly, but not exclusively, used in obstetrics. 15

next previous 1.2 progress check 16 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: when presented with a bony spine, identify correctly any individual vertebrae intervertebral foramina; what structures occupy this space? when presented with any intervertebral foramen, name the spinal nerve that emerges from it when presented with any spinal nerve, name the vertebrae above and below it the conus medullaris; what is it? adjacent to what vertebra is it generally located? dorsal and ventral rootlets and their relationship to a spinal nerve and a spinal segment what are the layers of the meninges? which contribute to the dural sac? where does it begin, superiorly, and where does it end, inferiorly? dura mater, denticulate ligaments where is the subarachnoid space? what does it contain? what is a potential space? is the subarachnoid space a potential space? why? what is the relationship between the subarachnoid space and the lumbar cistern? with reference to the adjacent vertebral bodies, what are the superior and inferior limits of the subarachnoid space? what is a lumbar puncture and where is it performed? what is the epidural space? is it a real or potential space? what does it contain and what is its clinical significance? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the exercise.
next previous 1.2 quiz skip 17 press or swipe next to start the quiz or skip to end exercise 1.2.

congratulations on finishing exercise 1.2 spinal cord and meninges! next exercise next exercise next exercise back to exercise selection back to exercise selection back to exercise selection review exercise 1.2 review exercise 1.2 review exercise 1.2 previous
1.3 spinal cord and nerves resources a model of a spinal cord segment next what you’ll need: exercise selection

next previous name the functional subdivisions of the nervous system. describe the fibre types within dorsal and ventral roots and how these differ from fibre types within spinal nerves and dorsal and ventral rami. define the term dermatome and myotome. describe the somatic and autonomic innervation of the body wall. describe the path of sympathetic outflow from the spinal cord to the body wall and limbs. 2 1.3 objectives

the spinal cord model represents a segment taken from the spinal cord, illustrating the different structural and functional groups of neurons, their relationships to each other and their connections to peripheral targets. work together with the model to ensure that everyone achieves the stated learning objectives, and can ultimately explain the answers to the questions in the progress check. while some of the content of this exercise will be familiar to you from prelab slm 1.2, this time, by working together and manipulating a 3-d model of a spinal cord segment and its associated nerves, you will develop a deeper understanding of the relationships between these structures. master this content now, in lab 1. it will return in different contexts and in different applications, throughout your anatomy and medical training. next previous 1.3 the spinal cord model 3

red arrows indicate the direction of information flow. * these numbers are found on the model in the lab next previous 1.3 motor fibres identify somatic motor fibres tas k identify visceral motor fibres tas k destined to control voluntary (striated) muscle in the body wall and limbs; they are colour-coded black. turn your attention to the spinal cord wedge model. destined to control smooth muscle and glands in the body wall and limbs; they are colour-coded red. identify ventral (anterior) roots, tas k 25, nerves that contain both of these subtypes of motor fibres. 4

carrying information toward the spinal cord: next previous 1.3 sensory fibres identify sensory fibres tas k 23, nerves that contain sensory fibres from all targets. identify dorsal (posterior) roots, tas k 5 the fibres monitoring receptors in the body wall / limbs are colour-coded yellow. the fibres monitoring receptors in the viscera are colour-coded green. you will learn about them in lab 2. red arrows indicate the direction of information flow.

ganglia are collections of neuronal cell bodies in the peripheral nervous system (pns) . the dorsal root (spinal) ganglion, 24. next previous 1.3 dorsal root ganglia identify on the model tas k note that these drgs contain tas k the cell bodies of pseudounipolar sensory neurons, the fibres of which convey information from receptors in the periphery to the spinal cord. these neurons thus apprise the cns of stimuli arriving from the body wall and limbs (yellow) and from the viscera contained within body cavities (green). 6

rami, 27 & 28, formed from the bifurcation of spinal nerves. because they arise from spinal nerves, these, too, contain both motor and sensory fibres. which are formed by the union of dorsal and ventral roots, and thus contain all the motor and sensory fibres described. next previous 1.3 spinal nerves, dorsal and ventral rami identify the spinal nerves. 26, tas k identify the dorsal and ventral tas k 7 dorsal and ventral rami give rise to the peripheral nerves that innervate the body wall and limbs, as well as the neck and the back of the head.

next previous 1.3 innervation of “the container” 8 in lab 1, the innervation of the body wall and limbs (“the container”) is considered. the innervation of viscera, including the heart, lungs and abdominal organs (“the contents”), will be considered in later labs cutaneous innervation by dorsal rami the targets of the nervous system in the body wall and limbs are threefold: skeletal (voluntary) muscle, innervated by somatic motor neurons vascular smooth (involuntary) muscle and both arrector pili muscle and glands in the skin, innervated by visceral motor neurons of the ans sensory receptors in the skin, muscle and joints, innervated by sensory neurons dorsal and ventral rami, branching from spinal nerves, are mixed nerves containing all of these fibre types, and give rise to the peripheral nerves that innervate all of these targets in the body wall and limbs. dorsal and ventral rami differ only in their distribution, not in their composition, i.e. they contain the same functional classes of neurons . dorsal rami are smaller; they only innervate target tissues overlying, and adjacent to, the vertebral column (the para-axial region), as illustrated in the accompanying figure. ventral rami are larger, and innervate target tissues inthe remainder of the body wall and in the limbs, a muchlarger area of distribution necessitating a larger nerve.

pop out the figure below to see that somatic motor nerve fibres in the dorsal ramus innervate skeletal muscle of the para-axial region, while somatic motor nerve fibres in the ventral ramus innervate all other skeletal muscles. somatic motor neurons are multipolar ; their cell bodies are located within the spinal cord. motor neurons (black), the axons of which synapse directly onto the target skeletal muscle in the body wall or limbs. next previous 1.3 the spinal cord model: somatic motor neurons identify the cell bodies of somatic tas k 9

a myotome is the group of muscle cells controlled by the somatic motor fibres contained within a single spinal nerve, and therefore arising from a single spinal level. next previous 1.3 dermatomes and myotomes a dermatome is the area of skin supplied by the cutaneous sensory fibres contained within a single spinal nerve and therefore arising from a single spinal level. there is a dermatome that corresponds to every spinal nerve / segment, except c1. 10

next previous 1.3 sympathetic innervation of the body wall 11 remember, at this point (day 1) in your anatomy training, you are learning about the innervation of the container, not the contents. remember that the targets of the autonomic nervous system in the body wall and limbs are threefold: vascular smooth muscle, and in the skin, arrector pili muscle and glands . these targets in the body wall and limbs are innervated exclusively by the sympathetic nervous system. there is no parasympathetic innervation of the body wall and limbs. once you recover from this shocking news, carry on…. recall that the sympathetic outflow from the cns to all peripheral targets originates in the spinal cord, between levels t1 and l2. from here, sympathetic outflow must be distributed throughout the walls of the container, from “stem to stern” . how this happens is the topic of the next three slides…..

sympathetic motor neurons in the spinal cord (red); these are multipolar neurons, like somatic motor neurons. however, note: sympathetic ganglia are bilaterally paired, and each serves its own side of the body. next previous 1.3 the white ramus communicans identify the cell bodies of the tas k unlike somatic motor neurons, they do not synapse directly onto their target. follow the fibres through the ventral root (25) and spinal nerve (26). from there, they enter a sympathetic ganglion (*) via a white ramus communicans (30). this is the preganglionic neuron, and its fibre the preganglionic axon . 12

pop out the figure below to see that within the sympathetic ganglion, the preganglionic sympathetic neurons synapse onto a second, postganglionic neuronal cell body , which gives rise to a postganglionic axon. next previous 1.3 the grey ramus communicans communicans, 29 . the postganglionic fibre re-enters the spinal nerve via the grey ramus communicans and is distributed to identify on the model the grey ramus tas k sympathetic targets in the para-axial region via the dorsal ramus or to targets in all other 13 body regions via the ventral ramus. so, while skeletal muscle is innervated directly by somatic motor neurons of the spinal cord, the innervation of smooth muscle and glands involves a two-neuron chain, with the second neuron occupying a ganglion in the pns.

next previous 1.3 there must be more to it… 14 there must be more to the distribution of sympathetics to the body wall…. remember: sympathetic outflow arises from spinal cord levels t1 – l2 only . therefore, the distribution of sympathetic outflow described so far only explains the delivery of sympathetic fibres to the corresponding t1-l2 dermatomes. we must understand the distribution of sympathetics to dermatomes above t1 and below l2. this is where the sympathetic chain comes in…

nerves connect the sympathetic ganglia, thereby forming the bilaterally-paired, sympathetic chains or trunks. the sympathetic chains extend above t1 into the neck, and below l2, to the level of the coccyx. the final pair of ganglia fuse, anterior to the coccyx, forming the ganglion impar. the sympathetic chains provide a means by which sympathetic outflow from the t1 - l2 spinal levels is distributed to dermatomes above and below. next previous 1.3 the sympathetic chains 15

next previous 1.3 distribution of sympathetics via the chains 16 down the sympathetic chain to access ganglia above t1 or below l2. from these ganglia, postganglionic axons destined for targets in dermatomes above t1 or below l2 leave the chain via a grey ramus communicans to join a spinal nerve . from there, sympathetics are delivered via the dorsal and ventral rami. as illustrated in the accompanying figure, sympathetic preganglionic axons arising from the spinal cord between t1 and l2 (solid blue line), and postganglionic axons arising from a sympathetic ganglion (dotted blue line), may travel up or

(hint: these branch from dorsal and ventral rami.) what distinguishes dorsal and ventral rami? what is the relationship between a dermatome, a spinal nerve, and its dorsal and ventral rami? what is a myotome? compare the structure and function of pseudounipolar and multipolar neurons. give an example of where each is located. compare the structural and functional type(s) of neuronal cell bodies contained in the chain ganglia and in the dorsal root (spinal) ganglia? explain how sympathetics are distributed to dermatomes t1 - l2. explain how sympathetics are distributed to dermatomes above t1 and below l2. explain why there are grey rami communicantes associated with all spinal nerves, but white rami communicantes associated only with spinal nerves t1-l2. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next exercise.

1b intro to the nervous system next exercise selection objectives: when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the features of a neuron and how these differ between multipolar and pseudounipolar types. describe the structural subdivisions of the nervous system (ns). describe the functional subdivisions of the nervous system (ns). describe the fibre types within dorsal and ventral roots and how these differ from fibre types within spinal nerves, and dorsal and ventral rami. describe the concept of dermatomes and myotomes. describe the somatic and autonomic innervation of the body wall. describe the path of sympathetic outflow from the spinal cord to the body wall and limbs.

neurons are both structurally and functionally polarized; i.e. the two ends are different from each other, both physically and functionally. neurons function in information transfer, and information is conducted unidirectionally, from the input “pole” of the neuron to its output “pole”. dendrites: input numerous, highly branched, tapering, short cell body (soma): input genetic and metabolic centre of cell axon (“nerve fibre”): integration, output 1 axon / cell, of variable length, \ neurons may fxn. locally or distantly may have axon collaterals; end as: synaptic terminals: transfer of info chemical transfer of info to the target cell via synaptic transmission target cell type varies (nerve, muscle, gland) next previous 1b neurons are “polarized” 5/20 a b c d electrical transfer of info 2

multipolar neuron: most common; e.g.. motor neurons, which contact muscle, interneurons which communicate over short distances, etc. numerous dendrites, single axon information is received by dendrites, transferred via an axon to the synaptic terminals (pseudo)unipolar neuron: sensory neurons, which monitor the body wall, limbs and internal organs single process arises from cell body, divides into two branches peripheral process begins as dendrites in the body wall, limbs or a visceral target, which merge to from an axon that extends from the target tissue in the periphery to the cns central process enters cns, ends as synaptic terminals again, information is received by dendrites, transferred via an axon to the synaptic terminals information flow information flow next previous 1b neuronal structure varies 3

structurally, the nervous system is subdivided into the central nervous system, cns, and the peripheral nervous system, pns. the cns is comprised of the brain and spinal cord. the pns is everything else: peripheral nerves and ganglia. peripheral nerves include: the cranial nerves, which arise from the brain and brainstem, and the spinal nerves, which arise from the spinal cord, and all nerves that branch from either. ganglia are collections of neuronal cell bodies (soma) outside the brain and spinal cord; i.e. in the periphery. 33 bilaterally paired spinal nerves arise from the spinal cord to emerge from between adjacent vertebrae. they are named accordingly: spinal nerves c1 - c8 are associated with the cervical vertebrae spinal nerves t1 - t12, associated with the thoracic vertebrae spinal nerves l1 - l5 are associated with the lumbar vertebrae spinal nerves s1 - s5 are associated with the sacrum, and spinal nerves co1 - co3 are associated with the coccyx next previous 1b structural subdivisions of the nervous system 4

functionally, the nervous system is subdivided into the somatic and visceral (autonomic) nervous systems. these subdivisions are defined by their targets. somatic nervous system sons this subdivision innervates the body wall, limbs, and much of the neck and extracranial structures its motor component controls skeletal (voluntary) muscle in these body regions its sensory component monitors receptors in these body regions autonomic nervous system ans this subdivision innervates viscera and glands its motor component controls smooth (involuntary) muscle (found in viscera other than the heart), cardiac muscle (found only in the heart) and glands, its sensory component monitors the activity and health of visceral organs next previous 1b functional subdivisions of the nervous system 5

the autonomic nervous system can be further subdivided anatomically and functionally into the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems. the parasympathetic nervous system dominates during resting conditions. it arises from the brainstem and from spinal segments s2 - s4. the sympathetic nervous system dominates during stressful or emergency conditions. it arises from spinal segments t1 – l2. next previous 1b subdivisions of the ans 6

nervous system somatic nervous system autonomic nervous system motor to voluntary muscle motor to involuntary muscle & glands sensory to head, neckbody wall, limbs sensory to viscera sympatheticnervous system parasympatheticnervous system next previous 1b summary: functional subdivisions of the nervous system 7

the remainder of this slm focuses primarily on the somatic nervous system, and its innervation of the body wall and limbs. in lab 2 you will be introduced to the innervation of thoracic viscera, and in lab 3 you will be introduced to the innervation of abdominal viscera. next previous 1b the somatic nervous system 8

red arrows indicate the direction of information flow. * these numbers are found on the model in the lab next previous 1b motor axons of the ventral root 9 the accompanying diagram shows a wedge of the spinal cord and the nerves and ganglia associated with it. in the diagram, identify the multipolar somatic and visceral motor axons, together in the anterior (ventral) root. click here for a caveat: the somatic motor axons are destined to innervate skeletal muscle of the body wall and limbs. this muscle you can move of your own volition. the visceral motor fibres are destined to innervate smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands. these structures are not under your voluntary control. the ventral root is a peripheral nerve that contains both of these subtypes of motor axons.

next previous 1b sensory axons of the dorsal root 10 red arrows indicate the direction of information flow. in the accompanying diagram, identify the sensory axons in the posterior (dorsal) root the dorsal root is a peripheral nerve that contains sensory fibres from both the body wall and limbs, and from the viscera contained within body cavities.

next previous 1b dorsal root ganglia 11 red arrows indicate the direction of information flow. in the accompanying diagram, identify the dorsal root (spinal) ganglion, commonly known as the drg. ganglia are collections of neuronal cell bodies in the peripheral nervous system (pns). notice that drg contain the cell bodies of pseudounipolar sensory neurons , the fibres of which convey sensory information from receptors in the periphery to neurons of the spinal cord. these neurons thus apprise the cns of stimuli arriving from the body wall and limbs and from the viscera contained within body cavities.

next previous 1b spinal nerves and branches 12 red arrows indicate the direction of information flow. in the accompanying diagram, identify the spinal nerve. notice that the spinal nerve, formed by the union of the ventral root (motor) and dorsal root (sensory) is a mixed nerve containing both motor and sensory fibres. identify the dorsal and ventral rami . the dorsal and ventral rami are formed by the bifurcation of the spinal nerve, and are therefore also mixed nerves. notice that the dorsal ramus is depicted as being smaller than the ventral ramus; this is because the dorsal ramus innervates a smaller portion of the body than the ventral ramus, as will be explained next.

in lab 1, the innervation of the body wall and limbs (“the container”) is considered. the innervation of viscera, including the heart, lungs and abdominal organs (“the contents”), will be considered in later labs next previous 1b innervation of “the container” cutaneous innervation by dorsal rami 13 the targets of the nervous system in the body wall and limbs are threefold: skeletal (voluntary) muscle, innervated by somatic motor neurons vascular smooth (involuntary) muscle and both arrector pili muscle and glands in the skin, innervated by visceral motor neurons of the ans sensory receptors in the skin, muscle and joints, innervated by sensory neurons dorsal and ventral rami, branching from spinal nerves, are mixed nerves containing all of these fibre types, and innervate all of these targets in the body wall and limbs. dorsal and ventral rami differ only in their distribution, not in their composition, i.e. they contain the same functional classes of neurons . dorsal rami are smaller; they only innervate target tissues overlying, and adjacent to, the vertebral column (the para-axial region), as illustrated in the accompanying figure. ventral rami are larger, and innervate target tissues in the remainder of the body wall and in the limbs, a much larger area of distribution necessitating a larger nerve.

next previous 1b dorsal and ventral rami 14 on one side, notice that the somatic motor axon passes into the dorsal ramus to synapse onto intrinsic back muscles, the muscles in the paravertebral region of the back. on the other side, notice that the somatic motor axon passes into the ventral ramus to synapse onto any and all other muscles in the body wall and limbs. sensory axons accompany motor axons through both, to monitor receptors in the corresponding body regions. the accompanying diagram shows a wedge of the spinal cord, the nerves and spinal ganglia associated with it, and the synapse between somatic motor neurons and their target skeletal muscle. the contact between a somatic motor neuron and its target muscle occurs at the neuromuscular junction, or nmj. on both sides of the illustration, trace the axon of the multipolar somatic motor neuron (blue) from its cell body in the spinal cord, through the ventral root and spinal nerve.

a myotome is the group of muscle cells controlled by the somatic motor fibres contained within a single spinal nerve, and therefore arising from a single spinal level. this means that each movement is controlled by one, or perhaps two spinal levels. this is of great clinical significance; weakness of a specific movement can help a clinician to localize a lesion to a specific spinal nerve or level. next previous 1b dermatomes and myotomes a dermatome is the area of skin supplied with cutaneous sensory fibres originating from a single spinal nerve, and therefore arising from a single spinal level. cutaneous sensory fibres are distributed to the dermatome by both the dorsal and ventral rami. in general, there is a dermatome that corresponds to every spinal nerve / segment, except c1. this means that a sensory deficit in a specific region of skin can help a clinician to localize a lesion to a specific spinal level or nerve . 15

next previous 1b sympathetic innervation of the body wall 16 remember, at this point (day 1) in your anatomy training, you are learning about the innervation of the container, not the contents. remember that the targets of the autonomic nervous system in the body wall and limbs are threefold: vascular smooth muscle, and in the skin, arrector pili muscle and glands . these targets in the body wall and limbs are innervated exclusively by the sympathetic nervous system. there is no parasympathetic innervation of the body wall and limbs. recall that the sympathetic outflow from the cns to all peripheral targets originates in the spinal cord, between levels t1 and l2. from here, sympathetic outflow must be distributed throughout the walls of the container, from “stem to stern” . how this happens is the topic of the next three slides…..

note: sympathetic ganglia are bilaterally paired, and each serves its own side of the body. next previous 1b preganglionic sympathetic axons 17 the accompanying diagram shows a wedge of the spinal cord at the t10 level and the nerves and ganglia associated with it. it highlights the distribution of sympathetics from this representative segment of the spinal cord between t1 and l2 to its associated dermatome. recall that the axons of somatic motor neurons emerge from the spinal cord to synapse directly on their target skeletal muscle . this is not the case for sympathetic motor neurons. in the accompanying diagram, follow the sympathetic axon (solid blue line) from its multipolar cell body in the spinal cord, through the ventral root and into the spinal nerve. from there, follow the axon through the white ramus communicans to the sympathetic ganglion. this sympathetic neuron is termed the “preganglionic neuron”, and its fibre the “preganglionic axon” .

note in the accompanying figure that within the sympathetic ganglion, the preganglionic sympathetic axons synapse onto a second, multipolar, postganglionic sympathetic neuron, which gives rise to a postganglionic axon (dotted blue line). if the target of the sympathetic postganglionic neuron is smooth muscle or glands in the body wall or limbs, then the postganglionic axon travels back to the spinal nerve via the grey ramus communicans . from there, sympathetics are distributed to targets in the para-axial region of the body wall via the dorsal ramus, and to targets in all other tissues of the body wall and the limbs via the ventral ramus. in the rami, they are accompanied the somatic motor and sensory fibres described earlier (not shown). in lab 2 you will learn that if the target of the postganglionic neuron is not the container, i.e. is not in the body wall or limbs, but is a visceral organ in, for instance, the thoracic or abdominal cavity, then the sympathetic postganglionic axon will not pass back to the spinal nerve via the grey ramus communicans. in this case, the sympathetic postganglionic axon will form distinct visceral nerves. next previous 1b postganglionic sympathetic axons 18

next previous 1b there must be more to it… 19 so far, the t10 dermatome was used as an example to explain the distribution of sympathetics to the t1-l2 dermatomes, as illustrated in the accompanying figure. however, sympathetics are distributed to dermatomes above t1 and below l2…..

sympathetic ganglia are connected by nerves, and thus form bilaterally-paired, sympathetic chains or trunks. the sympathetic chains extend above t1 into the neck, and below l2, to the level of the coccyx. the sympathetic chains form a distribution system that delivers sympathetics to the skin covering the entire body. sympathetic outflow from spinal levels t1 to l2 (solid blue lines) can travel up or down the sympathetic chains to reach ganglia above t1 and below l2. next previous 1b the sympathetic chains 20

next previous 1b distribution of sympathetics via the chains 21 up or down the sympathetic chain to access ganglia above t1 or below l2. from these ganglia, postganglionic axons (dotted blue lines) destined for targets in dermatomes above t1 or below l2 leave the chain via a grey ramus communicans to join a spinal nerve. from there, sympathetics are delivered via the dorsal and ventral rami. as illustrated in the accompanying figure, sympathetic preganglionic axons arising from the spinal cord between t1 and l2 (solid blue line), and postganglionic axons arising from a sympathetic ganglion (dotted blue line), may travel

next previous 1b summary: peripheral nerves 22 peripheral nerves that supply target tissues in the body wall and limbs, as distinct from those that supply visceral organs, contain: somatic motor axons that control skeletal muscle, sympathetic motor axons that control smooth muscle and glands, and sensory axons that monitor receptors in the skin amongst other tissues. sensory and motor axons are segregated between the dorsal and ventral roots, respectively. spinal nerves and their branches, including dorsal and ventral rami, are mixed nerves containing both sensory and motor fibres. sympathetic outflow to the body wall and limbs originates in the spinal cord in levels t1-l2, but is distributed to dermatomes throughout the body by means of the sympathetic chain.

1.4 a somatic plexus resources brachial plexus prosection next what you’ll need: exercise selection

1.4 objectives next previous describe the regional distribution of dorsal and ventral rami. describe the formation of a nerve plexus. describe how the components of a nerve plexus create peripheral nerves consisting of fibres from multiple spinal levels. describe how sensory or motor loss can follow a spinal level or peripheral nerve pattern, and how to differentiate between the two. 2

spinal nerves emerge bilaterally from the intervertebral foramen between adjacent vertebrae. spinal nerves give rise to somatic nerves , which innervate the body wall and limbs. somatic nerves, like the spinal nerves from which they are derived, are mixed nerves, containing both sensory and motor fibres. the targets of somatic nerves are threefold: sensory fibres monitor receptors in the skin, skeletal muscle and joints somatic motor fibres control voluntary (skeletal) muscle and sympathetic postganglionic fibres control smooth muscle and glands in the body wall and limbs. next previous 1.4 somatic nerves innervate the body wall and limbs 3

spinal nerves are very short and bifurcate immediately into dorsal and ventral rami. the dorsal rami proceed posteriorly to innervate these three target tissues in the paravertebral (para-axial) region. the ventral rami proceed anteriorly to innervate these three target tissues in the lateral and anterior aspects of the body wall, as well as in the limbs. because they innervate a larger bulk of tissue, the ventral rami are always larger than the dorsal rami. next previous 1.4 dorsal rami innervate the paravertebral region 4

in the case of the limbs, the ventral rami first form somatic plexuses , which give rise to the peripheral nerves found in the upper and lower limbs. this emodule endeavors to familiarize you with the basic structure of somatic plexuses, and the characteristics of the peripheral nerves that arise from them. next previous 1.4 ventral rami form plexuses for innervation of the limbs 5 in lab 2 and beyond, you will learn about autonomic / visceral plexuses, and how they compare in composition to somatic plexuses. in a plexus, fibres from different origins overlap and intermingle with each other . the specimen you will study during this exercise is a brachial plexus prosection. the brachial plexus is one of a number of somatic plexuses in the body, and is being used here as a tool to teach the concept of a somatic plexus.

unwrap the specimen of the brachial plexus provided. next previous 1.4 c5-t1 ventral rami form the brachial plexus spinal nerves emerging from the intervertebral foramina. these are the “roots” of the brachial plexus. identify the ventral rami of the c5 through t1 tas k the c5 and c6 ventral rami join to form the superior trunk. identify the trunks: tas k 6 nerves arising from the roots will contain fibres only from the one spinal level. the c7 ventral ramus continues independently as the middle trunk. the c8 and t1 ventral rami join to form the inferior trunk. it should make sense to you that: damage to the superior trunk will affect targets of both the c5 and c6 spinal nerves / levels. damage to the inferior trunk will affect targets of both the c8 and t1 spinal nerves / levels.

each of the three trunks bifurcate, and the divisions thus formed join to create the lateral, medial and posterior cords of the brachial plexus. the cords of the brachial plexus are named according to their position relative to the axillary artery. 1.4 divisions combine to form cords next previous the axillary artery (if present) the cords of the brachial plexus relative to the axillary artery. identify on the prosection: tas k by looking at the specimen*: answer the following questions tas k 7 *to answer these questions, follow each cord back to its roots. what spinal levels / nerves contribute to the lateral cord? what spinal levels / nerves contribute to the medial cord? what spinal levels / nerves contribute to the posterior cord?

1.4 terminal branches of the brachial plexus next previous plexus, and having your colleagues tell you the spinal levels that contribute to each. next, identify the terminal branches, of the brachial plexus, as follows: take turns pointing to the various roots, trunks and cords of the brachial tas k 8 place a probe or a finger underneath the lateral and medial cords and the nerves that arise from them, and notice that they form the shape of the letter “m” . identify the musculocutaneous nerve (c5-c6) as the continuation of the lateral cord. identify the median nerve (c6-t1) in the middle , formed by contributions from both the lateral and medial cord. identify the ulnar nerve (c8-t1) as the continuation of the medial cord. now, gently move these cords and nerves aside and isolate the posterior cord. observe that the posterior cord gives rise to the axillary nerve (c5-c6) before continuing as the radial nerve (c5-t1). notice, that the spinal levels that contribute to a terminal branch may be a subset of those contained within the cord(s) that gives rise to it! put a moist cloth over the prosection for now.

1.4 the terminal branches innervate the arm next previous 9 these terminal branches of the brachial plexus arise from the cords and are the major peripheral nerves of the upper limb. again, it is very important to realize that a terminal branch of the brachial plexus might not contain fibres from all levels present in the cord that forms it. an example is the musculocutaneous nerve. it arises from the lateral cord (c5-c7), but clinically-speaking, contains fibres from c5 and c6, only. therefore, knowing the brachial plexus provides a solid framework on which to begin to learn and remember the composition of peripheral nerves, but one must ultimately learn these exceptions. you will be taught these exceptions in cpc-3. for now, in itm, we’ll stick to the basics, and those nerves that have a predictable composition, based on the structure of the brachial plexus. at this point, we will use one terminal branch of the brachial plexus, the median nerve, as an example to compare and contrast the distribution of spinal nerves vs. peripheral nerves, and further explore the concepts of the dermatome and myotome.

a dermatome is the area of skin supplied by the cutaneous sensory fibres contained within a single spinal nerve and therefore arising from a single spinal level. a myotome is the group of muscle cells controlled by the somatic motor fibres contained within a single spinal nerve, and therefore arising from a single spinal level. these muscle cells may be distributed, during development, into several different muscles, and can therefore control one or more movements. myotomes of the upper limb dermatomes of the upper limb 1.4 dermatomes and myotomes next previous 10 notice, in the accompanying illustration, for instance, that abduction of the shoulder is a c5 movements, as is, in part, flexion of the elbow.

since peripheral nerves in the limbs arise from the overlapping of fibres within a somatic plexus, they may contain sensory and motor fibres originating from multiple spinal nerves / levels. you’ve just demonstrated that to yourself through your study of the brachial plexus. therefore, the cutaneous distribution of a peripheral nerve will include portions of multiple dermatomes. for example, mark the pad of your thumb with the number “6”. that region of skin is included in the c6 dermatome. now, mark the pad of your middle finger with a “7”. that region of skin is included in the c7 dermatome. c6 and c7 fibres reach these portions of the hand via the same peripheral nerve, the median nerve, a terminal branch of the brachial plexus. 1.4 dermatomes next previous 11

musculocutaneous n. median n. ulnar n. radial n. radial n. radial n. radial n. musculocutaneous n. median n. ulnar n. axillary n. axillary n. anterior view posterior view next previous 1.4 sensory distribution of peripheral nerves 12 the cutaneous distribution of the median nerve includes the skin of the thumb, index and middle fingers, i.e. portions of both the c6 and c7 dermatomes. however, the c6 dermatome includes much more than just the pad of the thumb; it extends along much of the anterior aspect of the arm (see previous slide). cutaneous fibres from the c6 spinal nerve are distributed to the skin of the anterior arm, not by the median nerve, but by other peripheral nerves, including the musculocutaneous and radial nerves.

can provide the clinician with valuable information as to whether a lesion involves a spinal nerve or a peripheral nerve. next previous 1.4 clinical significance: sensory loss careful determination of the distribution of sensory loss info 13 for instance, if an area of cutaneous sensory loss includes the pad of the thumb and extends up the anterior portion of the forearm, but spares the pad of the middle finger, do you suspect a lesion of a spinal nerve or a peripheral nerve? conversely, if an area of cutaneous sensory loss includes the pads of both the thumb and middle finger, but spares the anterior aspect of the arm, do you suspect a lesion of a spinal nerve or a peripheral nerve? therefore the pattern of sensory loss speaks to where in the nervous system damage or disease has occurred, in this case, in a spinal nerve or in a peripheral nerve.

flexors of the wrist are innervated by the median nerve. both flexion and extension of the wrist , amongst other movements. however, these somatic motor fibres are delivered to their target muscles by two different peripheral nerves, the median nerve (for flexion of the wrist) and the radial nerve (for extension of the wrist). does weakness in both flexion and extension of the wrist suggest the involvement of a spinal nerve or a peripheral nerve? does weakness in flexion of the wrist, with sparing of extension of the wrist, suggest the involvement of a spinal nerve or a peripheral nerve? therefore the pattern of weakness speaks to where in the nervous system damage or disease has occurred. extensors of the wrist are innervated by the radial nerve. next previous 1.4 clinical significance: muscle weakness the c7 myotome is responsible for info posterior view anterior view 14

next previous 1.4 progress check 15 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures on the brachial plexus prosection and learned the answers to the following questions: explain why ventral rami are larger than dorsal rami. identify the roots of the brachial plexus (ventral rami of c5 - t1), the trunks of the brachial plexus (superior, middle and inferior), the cords of the brachial plexus (medial, lateral and posterior), and state, while examining the brachial plexus, the spinal nerves / levels that contribute to each. identify the terminal branches of the brachial plexus. you are not, at this point, expected to know the spinal levels that contribute to each. define the term dermatome. explain why the sensory distribution of a peripheral nerve consists of portions of multiple dermatomes. explain why a myotome may control more than one movement, and can, in fact may control antagonistic movements. explain how you can differentiate between muscular weakness due to damage to a spinal nerve from muscular weakness due to damage to a peripheral nerve. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next exercise.

1a anatomical nomenclature next exercise selection objectives: when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: understand, and use properly, the nomenclature of relative position and planes of section understand, and use properly, the nomenclature describing movement.

1a the importance of precise language next previous 2 it is important to know, and use properly, the language that describes movement in order to be able to communicate clearly with colleagues regarding patients. this avoids misunderstanding, improves care, and keeps patients safe. this slm describes this language, which will be used not only throughout your anatomy lessons, but by clinician teachers during your training and beyond; i.e. by colleagues throughout your career.

1a the anatomical position & directional nomenclature next previous the position of structures is described with the body in the anatomical position: erect posture, feet together, eyes forward, palms forward. terms are usually* relative anterior “in front of” vs. posterior “behind”, as compared to : ventral “toward the belly” vs. dorsal “toward the back” superior “above” vs. inferior “below” cranial / cephalic “toward the head” vs. caudal “toward the tail” (i.e. the coccyx in humans) medial “toward the midline” vs. lateral “away from the midline” median* is an absolute term proximal “toward the beginning” vs. distal “toward the end” re. limbs; also tubular structures such as the digestive and genitourinary systems superficial “toward the surface” vs. deep “away from the surface” 3

1a sectional nomenclature next previous 4 sagittal plane separates the body into right and left portions. a midsagittal section passes through the midline, dividing the body into right and left halves . a parasagittal section misses the midline, creating right and left portions of unequal size . the sagittal plane is oriented parallel to the long axis of the body. sectioning produces a 2d representation of a 3d structure. it shows only the structures that are in the plane of section. structures outside the plane of section are not seen. frontal or coronal plane separates the body into anterior and posterior portions. the coronal plane is oriented parallel to long axis of the body. transverse or cross-sectional plane separates the body into superior and inferior portions. the transverse plane is oriented perpendicular to the long axis of the body in humans, is equivalent to the horizontal plane

next previous 5 1a nomenclature of movement movement between two or more bones occurs at joints. the starting point for these descriptions is taken to be the anatomical position. linear motion occurs when bones translate relative to each other, a movement that is often described as gliding; e.g. gliding occurs between the carpal bones of our wrists. angular motion occurs when the angle between two bones changes. flexion and extension are antagonistic movements that occur in the sagittal plane, therefore moving a body part anteriorly or posteriorly. flexion decreases the angle between articulating elements, extension increases the angle between articulating elements . there is one exception to this definition . abduction and adduction are antagonistic movements that occur in the coronal plane, relative to the midline of the body. abduction is a movement away from the midline, adduction is a movement toward the midline. abduction and adduction occur at the shoulder and hip, for example, when we do jumping jacks . rotation occurs around the long axis of a bone or structure. medial and lateral rotation occur in the limbs when we rotate them inward, toward the midline and outward, away from the midline, respectively. medial and lateral rotation occur at the shoulder and hip, for example . left / right rotation occurs with rotation of the vertebral column around its long axis . lateral flexion or lateral bending is a movement specific to the vertebral column, in which we bend from side to side, as in sliding our hand down the lateral aspect of the leg .

1 The central nervous system (CNS) includes the brain and spinal cord; the peripheral nervous system is everything else, including peripheral nerves (derived from spinal and cranial nerves) and ganglia.

2 pseudounipolar = a neuron whose cell body extends off the side of its fibre (axon); see slide 7

1 ramus = arm; rami = arms

2 bifurcation = branching into two

1 innervation = to supply with neural input

2 vascular = associated with blood vessels; vascular smooth muscle controls vascular resistance, and therefore blood flow to a region

3 arrector pili muscle is the smooth muscle that, when it contracts (involuntarily), makes your hair “stand on end”

4 para = on either side of; the para-axial region is on either side of the “axis”, or vertebral column
1 multipolar = a neuron whose fibre (axon) arises from the cell body; see slide 7.

derma = skin, tome = cut

myo = muscle, tome = cut

1 the “white ramus communicans” is white because its axon is coated by myelin, a lipid material that makes it white in fresh tissue.

2 pre = before; the preganglionic neuron comes carries information into the sympathetic ganglion from the spinal cord

1 the “grey ramus communicans” is grey because its axon is NOT coated in myelin, and is therefore grey relative to myelinated fibres

2 post = after; the postganglionic neuron comes carries information away from the sympathetic ganglion toward the target tissue

3.viscera (pl), viscus (s), L. = internal organs
